Netanyahu says Israel needs 'no approval' to strike Gaza
description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asserted Israel's sovereignty in national security decisions, emphasizing self-defense and independent action. He stated Israel will determine acceptable international forces for a Gaza security force, rejecting a role for Turkey. These remarks followed discussions in Washington regarding the Gaza Strip's future and a fragile ceasefire.

title: GM layoffs: Engineers fired on Microsoft Teams; Says it's business, not you
description: General Motors has let go of over 200 salaried employees, mainly CAD engineers, at its Michigan tech campus. This move, part of a restructuring to boost profits, follows strong third-quarter earnings and a raised financial outlook. GM stated the layoffs target execution roles to enhance core design capabilities. This comes as the automotive sector sees broader workforce reductions.

title: How Lauren Kyle McDavid is shaping Edmonton’s design and lifestyle culture
description: While the Oilers faced a Stanley Cup Final loss, Lauren Kyle McDavid is forging her own path in Edmonton. Her innovative Trove Living concept, blending furniture, design, and a social hub, has become a vibrant downtown destination.  Her fashion brand and community involvement further solidify her commitment to the city, mirroring Connor's ambition.

title: Bank holiday on Chhath Puja: Will banks remain closed on Oct 27? Check state-wise list
description: Banks across several states will observe closures for Chhath Puja, with Bihar and Jharkhand experiencing two-day holidays and West Bengal a one-day closure. These state-specific holidays mean banking operations in other regions will proceed as usual. Digital banking services remain accessible for customers during this period.

title: Cognizant CEO to students: Hiring more graduates than ever; focus on AI
description: Cognizant CEO Ravi Kumar S announces the IT firm is hiring more school graduates than ever in 2025, actively recruiting liberal arts majors from community colleges alongside traditional STEM candidates. Kumar tells Fortune that AI creates entry-level opportunities by amplifying human potential rather than displacing workers. He advises students to focus on interdisciplinary skills, combining fields like history with computational abilities. The CEO emphasizes that as AI makes expertise accessible, applying intelligence becomes more valuable than specialisation, with faster paths to expertise for graduates who leverage AI tools effectively.
